Well-Ordered Crystals of TaI 5 . The Formation of the Ternary Iodide CsTaI 6
Katja Habermehl a , Ingo Pantenburg a , Peter Held b , and Gerd Meyer a, *
Köln, Institute für a Anorganische Chemie und b Kristallographie der Universität
Received November 26th, 2007.
Abstract. Well ordered single crystals of TaI 5 (orthorhombic, Pnma
(no. 62), a ϭ 1396.2(2), b ϭ 2009.5(4), c ϭ 660.7(1) pm, Z ϭ 8, R 1
for 967 reflections with I 0 >2σ(I 0 ): 0.0381) were obtained from a
reaction of the elements. The structure determination confirms
Müller's prediction of 1978. Single crystals of CsTaI 6 (monoclinic,
C2/c (no. 15), a ϭ 1362.3(2), b ϭ 709.9(1), c ϭ 1736.2(3) pm, β ϭ
128.77(1)°, Z ϭ 4, R 1 for 1140 reflections with I 0 >2σ(I 0 ): 0.0378)
text.body:
The system tantalum/iodine contains Ϫ as one might have expected
Ϫ as the most oxidized compound tantalum pentaiodide, TaI 5 [1].
The structure was previously determined from a one-dimensionally
disordered crystal [2]. It contains dimers of edge-connected
octahedra, Ta 2 I 10 . Ternary iodides ATaI 6 (with A representing an
alkali-metal ion) have apparently not been investigated previously.
We have now obtained well ordered single crystals of TaI 5 and of
the first ternary iodide of tantalum(V), CsTaI 6 [3].
Results and Discussion
Dark brown single crystals of TaI 5 were obtained from the elements
applying a 500Ϫ180°C temperature gradient [4a], a procedure re-
ported with a slightly different temperature gradient in Brauer's
handbook in 1962 [5]. The wall of a He-arc sealed tantalum tube
was oxidized with caesium triiodide, CsI 3 at 390°C whereby black
single crystals of CsTaI 6 were obtained [4b].
The crystal structure of TaI 5 [6] contains [TaI 6 ] octahedra sharing
common edges to [I 4/1 TaI 2/2 TaI 4/1 ] ϭ [Ta 2 I 10 ] ϭ (TaI 5 ) 2 dimers,
Fig. 1. The octahedra are distorted subject to repulsive forces of
the high-charged tantalum atoms centering the octahedra with
d(TaϪTa) ϭ 445.9(1) pm. The distortion is represented by three
different sets of TaϪI distances, around 263 and 270 pm for the
terminal iodine atoms and 292 pm for the bridging iodine atoms in
the centrosymmetric [Ta 2 I 10 ] dimers. These dimers are arranged as
Fig. 1 exhibits. An alternative description of the crystal structure
of TaI 5 is that of a hexagonal closest packing of iodide spheres
with one fifth of the octahedral interstices occupied by Ta V in a
way that the above-mentioned dimers occur.

text.body:
This structure, as now determined from a well-ordered single crys-
tal of TaI 5 , was already predicted in 1978 by Müller [10], see Fig.
1 (bottom). It was confirmed in 1979 although from a crystal with
a one-dimensional disorder along [100] [2]. The sub-structure was
determined in the space group Ccmm with lattice constants of a ϭ
697±1, b ϭ 2007±1, c ϭ 661±1 pm. It was also predicted that the
true structure would have a doubled a axis and would have to be
described in space group Pnma [10, 2]. These lattice constants
would then be in accord with those reported by Rolsten in 1958
[11], a ϭ 665, b ϭ 1395, c ϭ 2010 pm (space group Pbnm), which
compare well with the lattice constants of our crystal, a ϭ
1396.2(2), b ϭ 2009.5(4), c ϭ 660.7(1) pm (space group Pnma).
Thus, starting with an ideal structure with space group
P6 3 /m2/m2/c, the symmetry of the hexagonal closest packing, the
parallel orientation of the TaϪTa vectors leads via symmetry re-
duction of the 3-and 6-fold axes to an orthorhombic cell with a
feasible subgroup Cmcm (translationengleich, index 3). The loss of
half of the 16 symmetry elements of Cmcm generates the sub-group
Pmmn (klassengleich, index 2). Doubling of the unit cell creates
the sub-group Pnma (klassengleich, index 2). The respective
Bärnighausen family tree was already reported in Müller's paper of
1978 [10].
The crystal structure of CsTaI 6 [6] contains [TaI 6 ] Ϫ octahedra (Fig.
2) with TaϪI distances between 274 and 276 pm with an average
of 274.8 pm, very close to the mean TaϪI distance in TaI 5 ,
275.3 pm. These [TaI 6 ] Ϫ octahedra are isolated from each other.
Cs ϩ ions are in a cuboctahedral environment (Fig. 2) with d(Cs-I)
ranging from 402 to 415 pm; the average distance CsϪI, 406.5 pm,
is larger than that observed in CsI (395.6 pm [12]), in accord with
an increase of the coordination number from 8 (CsI) to 12 (CsTaI 6 ).
The crystal structure of CsTaI 6 [6] (for atomic parameters see Tab.
1) is the same as observed for a large number of A I M V Cl 6 type
compounds with A I ϭ K, Tl, NH 4 , Rb, Cs and M V ϭ Nb, Ta, Sb
[13, 14]. It was first determined for CsWCl 6 [15]. It may be under-
stood as a densest packing of, for the present example of CsTaI 6 ,
Cs ϩ and I Ϫ spheres forming [CsI 6 ] layers. These are stacked in the
fashion of a cubic-closest packing. One sixth of the octahedral
holes only produced by I Ϫ ions are occupied by Ta 5ϩ ions, see
Fig. 2 and ref. [13].

[4] a) TaI 5 : 0.47 g of tantalum pieces and 2.5 g of iodine were
sealed in an evacuated Duran ® glass ampoule of 15 cm length
under liquid-nitrogen cooling. The ampoule was put with its
ends in two furnaces which were put closely together. Both
furnaces were first heated to 500°C for three days. Then a
temperature gradient of 500°C (Ta) to about 180°C (I 2 ) was
applied for five days after which a dark crystalline substance
was secured in an argon-filled dry box.
b) CsTaI 6 : CsI 3 was prepared as dark red crystals by slow
evaporation of a saturated solution of cesium iodide and
iodine in ethanol. 0.2 g of CsI 3 (0.3 mmol), were filled under
dry-box conditions in a sealed tantalum tube which was then
jacketed by an evacuated Duran ® glass ampoule. The ensem-
ble was heated to 390°C for five days and then cooled slowly
to room temperature.
[5] G. Brauer, Handbuch der Präparativen Anorganischen Chemie,
Band II, S. 1152, F. Enke-Verlag, Stuttgart, 1962.
[6] Suitable single crystals of both TaI 5 and CsTaI 6 were selected
under a microscope in a dry box and sealed in thin-walled
glass capillaries. The single crystals were transferred to a
single-crystal X-ray diffractometer (Stoe Image Plate Diffrac-
tion System, IPDS I) to collect a complete intensity data set
at ambient temperature. Structure solution and refinement was
performed with the programs SHELXS-97 (direct methods)
and SHELXL-97 [7], scattering factors were from Inter-
national Tables for X-ray Crystallogaphy [8]. Data corrections
were carried out for Lorentz and polarization factors
and absorption (numerical with the aid of the programs X-
RED and X-SHAPE [9]). Further details of the crystal struc-
ture determinations may be obtained from the Fach-
informationszentrum Karlsruhe, D-76344 Eggenstein-
Leopoldshafen, Germany (fax: (ϩ49)7247-808-666; e-mail:
crysdata@fizkarlsruhe.de), on quoting the depository numbers
ICSD-418486 (TaI 5 ) and ICSD-418487 (CsTaI 6 ), the authors
and the journal citation
